{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2017}} In 2007, a series of '''anti-government protests''' took place across [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]]. The demonstrations peaked on 2 November 2007, when 50,000–100,000<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2007/11/03/world/europe/03tbilisi.html?_r=1&oref=slogin Thousands Rally in Capital Against Georgia President], ''The New York Times''</ref> rallied in downtown [[Tbilisi]], the capital of Georgia.<ref name="TearGas">{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7082317.stm |title=Tear gas used on Georgia protest |publisher=BBC News|accessdate=8 November 2007 |date=7 November 2007| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20071107171137/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7082317.stm| archivedate= 7 November 2007 | deadurl= no}}</ref> People protested against the allegedly corrupt government of president [[Mikheil Saakashvili]]. Protests triggered by detention of Georgian politician [[Irakli Okruashvili]] on charges of [[extortion]], [[money laundering]], and abuse of office during his tenure as defense minister of the country<ref>[http://www.rferl.org/featuresarticle/2007/09/2D3437D8-DFF1-4E8B-8411-7B7738FA60E3.html Former Defense Minister Detained In Georgia]. [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]]. 27 September 2007.</ref> were organized by the National Council, an ad-hoc coalition of ten opposition parties, and financed by the media tycoon [[Badri Patarkatsishvili]].<ref>[http://www.civil.ge/eng/article.php?id=16119 Patarkatsishvili Pledges to Finance Protest Rallies]. Civil Georgia. 28 October 2007.</ref> Demonstrations occurred both in September and November 2007 and were initially largely peaceful. The protests went downhill by 6 November 2007, but turned violent the next day when the [[Law enforcement in Georgia (country)|police]], using heavy-handed tactics, including tear gas and water cannon, unblocked [[Rustaveli Avenue]], Tbilisi's main boulevard, dislodged the protesters from the territory adjoining to the [[Parliament of Georgia|House of Parliament]], and prevented the demonstrators from resuming the protests. The government accused the Russian secret services of being involved in an attempted coup d'état and declared a nationwide [[state of emergency]] later that day which lasted until late 16 November 2007.
On 8 November 2007, President Saakashvili announced a compromise solution to hold an [[Georgian presidential election, 2008|early presidential election]] for 5 January 2008. He also proposed to hold a [[Georgian legislative election date referendum, 2008|referendum in parallel]] to snap presidential elections about when to hold [[Georgian legislative election, 2008|parliamentary polls]] – in spring as pushed for by the opposition parties, or in late 2008.<ref name="civil.ge">[http://www.civil.ge/eng/detail.php?id=16262 Saakashvili Calls Snap Presidential Polls, Referendum]{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. Civil Georgia. 8 November 2007.</ref>
It is said to have been the worst political crisis in Georgia since the [[Rose Revolution]] in 2003 that brought Saakashvili's government to power in the first place.<ref name="TearGas"/>
==Background== {{Georgia-Russia}} Georgia in 2003 underwent a [[Rose Revolution|change of leadership]] that saw the coming to power of [[Mikheil Saakashvili]] in 2004. Saakashvili, a U.S. trained lawyer and staunch advocate for closer integration with the [[NATO]] and [[European Union]], instituted reforms that saw the nation's GDP triple and corruption drop since taking office.<ref>[http://www.newsweek.com/id/69554 Protesting the CEO of Georgia] Newsweek 18 November 2007</ref> In 2006, the [[World Bank]] named Georgia as the top reformer in the world.<ref name="Reuters">[https://www.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idUSL0235425420071107 FACTBOX: Georgia's Saakashvili divides country]. [[Reuters]]. 7 November 2007.</ref> Despite the progress, a significant portion of Georgia's population still live below the poverty line and Georgia is one of the poorest countries in the [[Commonwealth of Independent States|CIS]]. Growing incomes are offset by rising inflation; radical economic reforms and a crackdown on the black market left thousands unemployed; and since the reforms, many Georgians are having to pay tax and utility bills in full. Although the Saakashvili government has declared war on corruption, its critics alleges corruption in Saakashvili's own team, including his uncle – the entrepreneur Temur Alasania – and several ministers. The opponents say the authorities use selective application of the law to sideline political opponents, and accuse Saakashvili of authoritarian rule. The government has also come under the fire of criticism due to the use of heavy-handed police against the 2006 prison riot, as well as due to the underinvestigated [[Sandro Girgvliani Murder Case|high-profile murder case]] involving police officers.<ref name="Reuters"/>
Saakashvili also inherited the issues of the Russian-backed [[diplomatic recognition|unrecognized]] breakaway republics of Abkhazia and South Ossetia, which seceded from Georgia in the early 1990s. As of the time of the demonstrations, they were de facto [[Independence|independent]] but [[de jure]] part of Georgia. Saakashvili had made it part of his agenda to reincorporate them through peaceful means.{{Dubious|date=November 2008}} Others within Saakashvili's government, such as the defence minister [[Irakli Okruashvili]] had been pushing for a military solution for these de facto republics.
Saaskashvili reassigned the [[Portfolio (government)|portfolio]] of Okruashvili from defence to Minister of the Economy in November 2006. It was believed that the reassignment came due to Okruashvili’s aggressive stance on the secessionist conflicts.<ref>[http://www.rferl.org/featuresarticle/2006/11/c3b48026-d616-4c76-8dbb-f4256c36577f.html Georgia: What Led To Defense Minister's Demotion?] RadioFreeEurope RadioLiberty 14 November 2006 By Liz Fuller</ref> Okruashvili subsequently resigned his post.<ref>[http://www.eurasianet.org/departments/insight/articles/eav111706a.shtml GEORGIA: FORMER DEFENSE MINISTER SUBMITS "SHOCK" RESIGNATION] EURASIA INSIGHT Molly Corso 17 November 2006</ref>
On 25 September 2007, he announced the formation of the new opposition Movement for United Georgia and unleashed criticism on President Saakashvili, accusing him of corruption, incompetency and human rights violations. He also raised new concerns around [[Zurab Zhvania]]'s death, challenging the official investigation point of view<ref>[http://www.geotimes.ge/index.php?m=home&newsid=6946 Okruashvili Ups Ante on Former Allies] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151018172701/http://www.geotimes.ge/index.php?m=home&newsid=6946 |date=18 October 2015 }} – ''The Georgian Times''</ref> and personally accused the Georgian president of planning the murder of businessman [[Badri Patarkatsishvili]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rferl.org/featuresarticle/2007/09/95075e67-2429-48bd-8731-1591a00cb7f7.html |title=Praise, Scorn For Accusations Against Georgia President |publisher=Rferl.org |date=26 September 2007 |accessdate=3 March 2012}}</ref><ref>[https://www.forbes.com/feeds/ap/2007/09/26/ap4157991.html Georgia's Ex-Minister Assails President] – Forbes, Associated Press</ref>
==Timeline== ===28 September 2007 protests=== Protests started on 28 September 2007. There was no major trouble reported at the rally, except for some minor scuffles between protesters and police when the protesters spilled out onto [[Rustaveli Avenue]], blocking Tbilisi's main thoroughfare in front of the parliament. Demonstrators were demanding early elections, more accountability and honesty in politics.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://news.independent.co.uk/europe/article3010190.ece | work=The Independent | location=London | title=Huge protests in Tbilisi demand election after corruption claims | first=Shaun | last=Walker | date=29 September 2007 | accessdate=22 April 2010 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071014223051/http://news.independent.co.uk/europe/article3010190.ece | archivedate=14 October 2007 | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
The rally was organized by an alliance of major opposition parties with the exception of the [[New Right (Georgia)|New Rights]] which distanced themselves from the manifestation stating that it was "not the way from one temple to another, it is substitute of one leader with another."<ref>[http://eng.primenewsonline.com/news/121/ARTICLE/15774/2007-09-28.html "New Rights" Not To Participate In Rally In Front Of Parliament]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. Prime News Online. 28 September 2007.</ref>
====Okruashvili's comments====
Previously, former Georgian Minister of Defense and long-time critic of Moscow's policy towards Georgia Irakly Okruashvili has lashed out at his former associate President [[Mikheil Saakashvili]]. Okruashvili had been sacked by the president, in November 2006, from his post of Defense Minister allegedly under pressure from the West in September 2006.<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idUSL2885338820070928 Thousands protest against Georgia president]. [[Reuters]]. 28 September 2007.</ref>
At the presentation of his party [[For United Georgia]], he accused Saakashvili of corruption, lobbying the interests of his own family,<ref>Okruashvili claimed he caught the president's uncle with a US$200,000 bribe three years ago.</ref> weakness towards separatists in Abkhazia and South Ossetia,<ref name="HugeRally">{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7018698.stm |date=28 September 2007 |accessdate=8 November 2007 |title=Huge rally against Georgia bleader |publisher=BBC| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20071109073137/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7018698.stm| archivedate= 9 November 2007 | deadurl= no}}</ref> and a lack of morals.<ref name="OkruashviliAccusations">{{cite news| url=http://en.rian.ru/analysis/20070926/81123901.html |title=Why did Okruashvili "attack" Saakashvili? |date=26 September 2007 |accessdate=8 November 2007 |publisher=en.rian.ru |last=Shesternina |first=Yelena| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20071105032922/http://en.rian.ru/analysis/20070926/81123901.html| archivedate= 5 November 2007 | deadurl= no}}</ref> Okruashvili also claimed that the Georgian government had intentionally obscured the true reasons behind the death of former Prime Minister [[Zurab Zhvania]]. Zhvania had died while Prime Minister in February 2005. Okruashvili said that Zhvania's corpse had been taken to the apartment where he was found dead.<ref name="OkruashviliAccusations"/><ref>Zurab Zhvania officially died of accidental poisoning with [[carbon monoxide]].</ref>
Okruashvili retracted his statements and admitted to the charges raised against him on 8 October 2007 on television, but he later said he made the statements due to being "psychologically pressured".<ref name="PhycPressure">{{cite news| url=http://www.messenger.com.ge/issues/1480_november_7_2007/1480_okruashvili.html |title=Okruashvili, a ‘political refugee’ in Germany, vows to unseat the president |publisher=messenger.com.ge |accessdate=8 November 2007 |date=7 November 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7033966.stm |work=BBC News | title=Georgian ex-minister 'confesses' | date=8 October 2007 | accessdate=22 April 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Asatiani |first=Salome |url=http://www.rferl.org/featuresarticle/2007/10/3cc45581-d86d-4885-bcf3-45097e1c290d.html |title=Georgia: In Televised About-Face, Ex-Minister Retracts Murder Claims – RADIO FREE EUROPE / RADIO LIBERTY |publisher=Rferl.org |date=8 October 2007 |accessdate=3 March 2012}}</ref>
Okruashvili left Georgia around 1 November 2007. He subsequently said he was forced into exile; the government said he left to seek medical treatment.<ref name="rfe1">{{cite web|url=http://www.rferl.org/featuresarticle/2007/11/129f6da9-b5b6-400d-9160-ea0e53baa35f.html |title=Georgia: Firebrand Okruashvili’s Televised Return Boosts Opposition – RADIO FREE EUROPE / RADIO LIBERTY |publisher=Rferl.org |date=6 November 2007 |accessdate=3 March 2012}}</ref> The following April he was granted [[political asylum]] by the government of France. In September 2008, a French court rejected Georgia's extradition request.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rt.com/Top_News/2008-09-10/France_wont_extradite_former_Georgian_defence_minister.html |title=France won't extradite former Georgian defence minister |publisher=Rt.com |date=10 September 2008 |accessdate=3 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100910201630/http://rt.com/Top_News/2008-09-10/France_wont_extradite_former_Georgian_defence_minister.html |archivedate=10 September 2010 |df= }}</ref> Okruashvili has been described as "a likely candidate to replace Saakashvili, if and when Georgian public opinion turns against the president."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.atimes.com/atimes/Central_Asia/JH12Ag02.html |title=Asia Times Online :: Central Asian News and current affairs, Russia, Afghanistan, Uzbekistan |publisher=Atimes.com |date=12 August 2008 |accessdate=3 March 2012}}</ref>
====Government's response==== [[File:Mikhail Saakashvili 2005May10.jpg|thumb|left|[[Mikhail Saakashvili]], Georgia's president]] Okruashvili's political comeback and his arrest coincided with Saakashvili's visit to New York City where he addressed the [[U.N. General Assembly]] and heavily criticized Russia's involvement in Georgia's breakaway territories.<ref>[http://www.civil.ge/eng/detail.php?id=15884 Saakashvili Attacks Russia in UN Speech]{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. ''Civil Georgia''. 26 September 2007.</ref> Meanwhile, [[Giga Bokeria]], an influential member of the [[Parliament of Georgia]] from the ruling [[United National Movement (Georgia)|United National Movement]] party, said by voicing stunning, but groundless accusations Okruashvili wanted "to create some kind of immunity and untouchable status." On 29 September, President Saakashvili headed to [[Upper Abkhazia]] where he attended opening of a new road linking Georgian-controlled areas in breakaway Abkhazia with Georgia proper. He made his first remarks on Okruashvili's accusations: {{quote|I want to tell you that personally for me it is very difficult what Okruashvili has done. I am accustomed to any accusations leveled against me and against my relatives. But this person [Okruashvili] – unlike those persons, who just believed in or made allegations – knows precisely that it is a lie.<ref>[http://www.civil.ge/eng/article.php?id=15912 Saakashvili Breaks Silence over Okruashvili]. Civil Georgia. 29 September 2007.</ref>}}
===2 November 2007 protests=== [[File:Protest in Georgia.jpg|thumb|left|Opposition protests in Tbilisi on 2 November 2007. The inscription says "I am not afraid" (Georgian).]] On 2 November 2007, tens of thousands of Georgians protested outside the parliament in the capital, Tbilisi, urging President Mikhail Saakashvili to step down. The crowd also called for early parliamentary elections. They accused Saakashvili of heading a corrupt, authoritarian government and wanted him to be ousted democratically.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7074585.stm |work=BBC News | title=Mass protest in Georgian capital | date=3 November 2007 | accessdate=22 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100420233228/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7074585.stm| archivedate= 20 April 2010 | deadurl= no}}</ref>
The protests continued in the following days;<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20071106.wgeorgia1106/BNStory/International/home | location=Toronto |work=Globe and Mail | title=globeandmail.com: World| accessdate= 6 November 2007 }}</ref> a televised statement from Okruashvili was seen as a boost in support for the opposition.<ref name="rfe1"/>
Twenty-three law enforcement officers were injured and 21 people were arrested during the riots.<ref>[http://www.civil.ge/eng/article.php?id=16252 21 People Arrested – Police]. Civil Georgia. 8 November 2007.</ref>
TV footage showed some protesters throwing stones at riot policemen. They were dispersed by police a second time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.civil.ge/eng/article.php?id=16227 |title=Online Magazine – Civil Georgia |publisher=Civil.ge |date=1 July 2001 |accessdate=3 March 2012}}</ref>
Two pro-opposition independent TV stations have gone off the air after [[Badri Patarkatsishvili]] declared that "Nobody should doubt that all my efforts, my financial resources including the last [[tetri]] will be applied for freeing Georgia from Fascist regime": [[Imedi TV]] (that is co-owned by the media tycoon [[Badri Patarkatsishvili]] who sponsored the National Council recently set up by the ten opposition parties and has pledged to finance the rallies until the government is removed) and Kavkasia, located in the same building as Imedi TV.<ref>CNN, [http://edition.cnn.com/2007/WORLD/europe/11/07/georgia.crisis.ap/index.html Georgia: State of emergency called], 11 July 2007</ref> Police officers in masks and assault rifles were seen sealing off the Imedi office.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.civil.ge/eng/article.php?id=16234 |title=Online Magazine – Civil Georgia |publisher=Civil.ge |date=1 July 2001 |accessdate=3 March 2012}}</ref> Shortly afterwards, Mikheil Saakashvili declared a [[state of emergency]] Georgia-wide to last for 15 days. As a result, news programs at all the private television stations will be shut down for 15 days.<ref>BBC, [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7083911.stm Georgia declares emergency state], 11 July 2007</ref> The publicly funded [[Georgian Public Broadcaster]] (GPB) remained the only station allowed to provide news coverage.<ref>[http://www.civil.ge/eng/article.php?id=16239 Emergency Rule in Georgia, News Coverage Curtailed]. Civil Georgia. 8 November 2007.</ref>
On 8 November, a "small group of students" gathered at [[Batumi]] State University to rally against what they saw as the "police violence" that had occurred the previous day. According to eyewitnesses interviewed by [[Human Rights Watch]], "police attacked the group without warning, chasing and beating protesters trying to flee." Holly Cartner, Executive Director [of] Europe and Central Asia Division at [[Human Rights Watch]] condemned what she described as "police attacks on peaceful protesters".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hrw.org/english/docs/2007/11/08/georgi17284.htm |title=Georgia: Police Beat Peaceful Protesters for Second Day (Human Rights Watch, 8 November 2007) |publisher=Hrw.org |date=8 November 2007 |accessdate=3 March 2012}}</ref>
Soon, Georgia's opposition announced the suspension of anti-government protests in Tbilisi.<ref>[http://www.voanews.com/english/2007-11-08-voa21.cfm Saakashvili Proposes Georgian Presidential Elections in January] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071109114059/http://www.voanews.com/english/2007-11-08-voa21.cfm |date=9 November 2007 }}. [[Voice of America|VOA News]]. 8 November 2007.</ref> Most of the opposition parties hailed President Saakashvili’s decision as the first step to end the political standoff, and agreed to the negotiations with [[Nino Burjanadze]], the parliamentary chairperson.<ref>[https://archive.is/20070611065820/http://www.civil.ge/eng/detail.php?id=16267 Crisis Receding as Election Season Begins to Unfold]. Civil Georgia. 9 November 2007.</ref>
By 9 November 2007, riot police and troops had been withdrawn from the main sites of 7 November unrest. On the same day, [[Ilia II]], [[Catholicos-Patriarch of All Georgia|Catholicos-Patriarch]] of the [[Georgian Orthodox Church]] met separately with Nino Burjanadze and opposition leaders and said that he was ready to mediate between the opposition and the authorities.
====Government's response==== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Riot police in Tbilisi 2007.jpg|thumb|[[Riot police]] in the streets of [[Tbilisi]].]] --> [[File:Tbilisi riot 2007.jpg|thumb|Protesters clash with riot police on 7 November 2007.]] Saakasvili commented the clashes by saying "We have been hearing for recent months that turmoil was expected in Georgia by autumn. We have been receiving this information from our intelligence" and that "alternative government has already been set up in Moscow".<ref>[http://www.civil.ge/eng/article.php?id=16229 Saakashvili Makes a Statement] Civil Georgia, 7 November 2007</ref>
Prime Minister [[Zurab Nogaideli]] said a coup attempt was made.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7083911.stm Georgia under state of emergency] BBC News, 8 November 2007</ref>
On 7 November, Georgia's Interior Ministry released taped audio and video material purporting to show some opposition leaders – Levan Berdzenishvili of the [[Republican Party of Georgia|Republican Party]], Giorgi Khaindrava of opposition group Equality Institute, [[Konstantine Gamsakhurdia (politician)|Konstantine Gamsakhurdia]], the leader of the [[Tavisupleba (political party)|Freedom Movement]] and [[Shalva Natelashvili]], the leader of [[Georgian Labour Party|Labor Party]] – cooperating with the Russian counter-intelligence service during a meeting with three Russian diplomats.<ref>[http://www.civil.ge/eng/article.php?id=16240 Georgia to Expel Three Russian Diplomats]. Civil Georgia. 8 November 2007.</ref>
[[Gigi Ugulava]], Tbilisi's mayor, defended the action by police, saying: "I was listening to one of the opposition leaders who was saying proudly they planned to pitch tents and set up a tent town in Tbilisi. "What we did is stop this because it is the will of the people not to have a tent town in Tbilisi."<ref>[http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/B38F9318-A9CB-42F9-9D61-EBCAA0654293.htm Georgia declares state of emergency] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071109105417/http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/B38F9318-A9CB-42F9-9D61-EBCAA0654293.htm |date=9 November 2007 }} Al Jazeera, 7 November 2007</ref>
====Criticism of government actions==== [[File:Demonstrations in Tbilisi, Georgia. 7 November 2007.jpg|thumb|Clashes in Tbilisi on 7 November 2007.]] The opposition leaders, NGOs and the public defender of Georgia have harshly criticised the government actions. The police was accused of excessiveness, and it was alleged that groups of organized civilians{{Citation needed|date=November 2007}} were also engaged in the crackdown on the protesters. Illegal arrests, beatings and intimidations were reported.<ref name=civil071112>[http://www.civil.ge/eng/article.php?id=16311 Ruling Party, Opposition End Second round of Talks] civil.ge 12 November 2007</ref> Concerns have been expressed about widespread practice of tapping private telephone conversations.<ref name=civil071118>[http://www.civil.ge/eng/article.php?id=16361] civil.ge 18 November 2007</ref> The government has been accused of media control.{{Citation needed|date=November 2007}} <onlyinclude> In December 2008, [[Sozar Subari]], Public Defender ([[Ombudsman]]) of Georgia, claimed he had evidence that then Georgia's [[Interior Minister]] [[Vano Merabishvili]] had ordered police to beat protesters, "mainly in the kidneys and the stomach."<ref name="ipn.ge">[http://www.ipn.ge/en/index.php?news=4741&hd_line=1] Sozar Subari Spoke about ‘The Last Supper’ of Merabishvili-Kezerashvili-Akhalaia-Adeishvili</ref> In his testimony before [[Parliament of Georgia|Georgian Parliament]], Subari claimed that he possessed evidence that [[Defense Minister]] [[Davit Kezerashvili]], [[Justice Minister]] [[Zurab Adeishvili]] and Davit Akhalaia (who had no official office then) had had a secret meeting at the office of Interior Ministry on 4 November 2007 where they had decided on the course of action for handling the demonstrations: <blockquote> "The interior minister ordered that the demonstrators be hit mainly in the kidneys and the stomach, or in the face only when necessary. The interior minister also said at the meeting that not a single participant in the action must escape unbeaten in order to teach them a lesson for the future."<ref name="ipn.ge"/><ref>[http://www.interfax.com/3/459460/news.aspx] Georgia minister ordered beating of demonstrators – ombudsman</ref> </blockquote> </onlyinclude>
===25 November 2007 protests=== On 25 November 2007, thousands of protesters staged a three-hour peaceful demonstration demanding the re-opening of Imedi TV and radio stations. The protest, organized by a nine party opposition coalition, gathered in an area called the Rike in Tblisi and then moved to the front of the [[Parliament of Georgia|Parliament]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.civil.ge/eng/article.php?id=16427 |title= Thousands Protest in Support of Imedi TV |publisher=[[civil.ge]] |date=25 November 2007 |accessdate =30 November 2007 }}</ref>
==International reaction== '''{{Flagu|United States}}''' – The United States welcomed the Georgian government’s decision to hold early presidential elections, while urging to end the state of emergency and restore all media broadcasts.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.state.gov/r/pa/prs/ps/2007/nov/94760.htm |title=Georgia: Need for Restraint and Respect for Rule of Law |publisher=[[US Department of State]] |date=8 November 2007 |accessdate=8 November 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071109164621/http://www.state.gov/r/pa/prs/ps/2007/nov/94760.htm |archivedate=9 November 2007 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> On 13 November 2007, Matthew Bryza, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for European Affairs and the top U.S. envoy to the Caucasus, told reporters that he would be very surprised if there had been a real threat from Russia to destabilize Georgia.<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idUSL1367375720071113 |title= U.S. says doubts Russia involved in Georgia strife |publisher=reuters |date=13 November 2007 |accessdate =15 November 2007 | first=James | last=Kilner }}</ref>
'''{{Flagu|Russia}}''' – The Russian Foreign Ministry rejected Saakashvili's accusations of backing the opposition rally calling it an "irresponsible provocation" designed by Georgian authorities to distract attention from domestic problems and blame them on a foreign scapegoat.<ref name=forbes>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110604002747/http://www.forbes.com/feeds/afx/2007/11/07/afx4312790.html State of emergency declared in Tbilisi] Forbes.com AFX News Limited 11 November 2007</ref> It later issued a statement heavily criticizing the Georgian government for police lawlessness, arrests of opposition leaders and human rights activists, ban on activities of the independent media and beating of foreign journalists.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.mid.ru/brp_4.nsf/0/3EDC26E7F81A26E2C325738D0060E85C |title= Statement by Mikhail Kamynin, the Spokesman of Russia's Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Regarding the Human Rights Situation in Georgia |publisher=[[Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Russia]] |date=8 November 2007 |accessdate =8 November 2007 }}</ref>
'''{{Flagu|Sweden}}''' – Foreign minister [[Carl Bildt]] said that 7 November was a "very dark day for Georgia", but praised the decision to hold early presidential elections, adding that all parties now have to "return to the democratic path". "This is also a way to address the simplistic propaganda that is currently blazoned abroad by the big neighbor in the north (Russia)" /.../ "and to secure long-term stability in the country."<ref>[http://carlbildt.wordpress.com/2007/11/08/liten-ljusning-i-georgien/ Liten ljusning i Georgien] Carl Bildt's weblog, 8 November 2007.</ref> Carl Bildt, who met with President Saakashvili in Tbilisi on 2 November, has repeatedly said that: "To support and help the young democracies (in Eastern Europe) /.../ is something we (Europe) must do."<ref>[http://www.dn.se/DNet/jsp/polopoly.jsp?d=1042&a=712381 I hälarna på resenären Carl Bildt] Dagens Nyheter, 4 November 2007.</ref>
'''{{flag|United Nations}}''' – [[Louise Arbour]], the [[UN High Commissioner for Human Rights]], rebuked Georgia for its "disproportionate use of force" against protesters and said it must uphold fundamental rights even under a state of emergency. In a statement, she also expressed support for Georgia's public defender, or human rights ombudsman, and voiced concern at the silencing of independent television stations in the former Soviet republic.<ref name=reuters>[https://www.reuters.com/article/latestCrisis/idUSL08332924 UN rights boss rebukes Georgia for use of force] reuters.com, Stephanie Nebehay, 8 November 2007</ref>
'''[[NATO]]''' – [[NATO Secretary General|Secretary General]] [[Jaap de Hoop Scheffer]] in a statement on 8 November 2007 said that "The imposition of Emergency Rule, and the closure of media outlets in Georgia, a Partner with which the Alliance has an Intensified Dialogue, are of particular concern and not in line with Euro-Atlantic values"<ref>[http://www.geotimes.ge/index.php?m=home&newsid=7700 Closure of Media Outlets Not in Line with NATO Values – Scheffer] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071014110607/http://www.geotimes.ge/index.php?m=home&newsid=7700 |date=14 October 2007 }} The Georgian Times, Civil Georgia 8 November 2007</ref>
'''{{flag|European Union}}''' – The EU foreign policy chief, [[Javier Solana]], urged restraint from both sides, saying "political differences should be resolved within the democratic institutions".<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7084357.stm Troops enforce Georgia emergency] BBC News, 8 November 2007</ref>
'''[[Human Rights Watch]]''' – On 20 December 2007, Human Rights Watch released a 102-page report, named ''Crossing the Line: Georgia’s Violent Dispersal of Protestors and Raid on Imedi Television'', criticising what it saw as the Government's "usage of excessive force" on protesters the police's raide on Imedi.<ref>[http://hrw.org/english/docs/2007/12/17/georgi17572.htm HRW report]. 12 December 2007.</ref>
==Aftermath== ===Crisis recedes=== On 8 November 2007, Saakashvili announced he was planning [[Georgian presidential election, 2008|snap presidential elections]] for 5 January 2008. He also proposed to hold a simultaneous [[Georgian legislative election date referendum, 2008|plebiscite]] about when to hold [[Georgian legislative election, 2008|parliamentary polls]] – in spring as pushed for by the opposition parties, or in late 2008. He also called for dialogue with the opposition parties which, he said, did not cooperate with the Russian intelligence, and promised to end the state of emergency within a few days.<ref name="civil.ge"/>
The Georgian authorities charged Patarkatsishvili, who had earlier left for London, with plotting a coup.<ref>[http://www.civil.ge/eng/article.php?id=16273 Patarkatsishvili Suspected of "Coup Plotting"]. Civil Georgia. 9 November 2007.</ref> He died on 12 February 2008, in London.
On 9 November 2007, the Parliament of Georgia, in a complete absence of opposition lawmakers, backed the presidential decree imposing state of emergency and restrictions on media on the entire territory of Georgia to be in force until late 22 November.<ref>[http://www.civil.ge/eng/article.php?id=16275 Parliament Backs Emergency Rules]. Civil Georgia. 9 November 2007.</ref>
On 10 November 2007, the talks regarding the election code resumed between the ruling and opposition parties.<ref>[http://www.civil.ge/eng/article.php?id=16311 Ruling Party, Opposition End Second round of Talks]. Civil Georgia. 12 November 2007.</ref>
The nationwide state of emergency was lifted at 7 pm local time on 16 November 2007, in accordance to the parliament's decree passed two days earlier.<ref>[http://www.civil.ge/eng/article.php?id=16350 State of Emergency Lifted]. Civil Georgia. 16 November 2007.</ref> All media sources resumed broadcasting with the exception of Imedi TV which returned on air on 12 December.<ref>[http://www.civil.ge/eng/article.php?id=16351 Kavkasia TV Back on Air]. Civil Georgia. 16 November 2007.</ref><ref>[http://www.civil.ge/eng/article.php?id=16565 Imedi Resumes Broadcasts]. Civil Georgia. 12 December 2007.</ref>
===Economic impact=== Robert Christiansen, the head of the IMF's Georgia mission, indicated that the turmoil and pre-election uncertainty has dented Georgia's image with investors, adding that recovery was possible. He added that "recent political developments add considerable uncertainty to the projected volume of inflows for the remainder of this year and 2008".<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idUSL1590594420071115 |title= Georgia to lift emergency, IMF says turmoil damaging |agency=Reuters |date=15 November 2007 |accessdate =15 November 2007 }}</ref>
According to Prime Minister [[Lado Gurgenidze]], during the November turmoils Georgian economy lost nearly half a billion dollars of potential investments.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.geotimes.ge/index.php?m=home&newsid=8201 |title = November Unrest Cost Economy USD 500 mln – PM |publisher = The Georgian Times |date = 14 December 2007 <!-- 10:20 --> |accessdate = 14 December 2007 <!-- 10:20 --> |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20080830182709/http://www.geotimes.ge/index.php?m=home&newsid=8201 |archive-date = 30 August 2008 |dead-url = yes |df = dmy-all }}</ref>

[[File:Brenda Cherry.jpg|thumb|Brenda Cherry]] '''Brenda Cherry''' (born March 19, 1958), is an American Civil Rights Activist from [[Paris, Texas]].
Cherry is the President and co-founder of Concerned Citizens for Racial Equality, a non-profit [[civil rights organization]] located in Paris, Texas. Founded in 2003, CCFRE co-sponsored events with the [[U.S. Department of Justice]], Lone Star Legal Aid, and the [[American Civil Liberties Union]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Justice Dept Intervene on Racial Tensions in Paris, TX (Public Meeting 1.29)|url=http://www.pr.com/press-release/128805|publisher=PR.com|accessdate=19 August 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Legal aid rally draws crowd|url=http://theparisnews.com/news/article_f4ce57b9-0e1a-5d4c-bc0d-85c9819316a6.html|publisher=TheParisNews.com|accessdate=19 August 2012}}</ref>
== Early life == Cherry grew up in Blossom Texas. Her late father, Zeb Reynolds, was a farmer, and her mother, Irene Whitney, was a domestic worker. She began school at T.G. Givens, which was then, a segregated school in Paris, Texas. She had to be bused 10 miles to the school even though there was a local school district in the town where she lived. After the schools were forced to integrate, she attended the formerly "whites only" school in Blossom. Cherry graduated from [[Prairiland High School]] in [[Pattonville, Texas]]. She went on to attend [[Paris Junior College]] and [[East Texas State University]]. Cherry worked as a Licensed Vocational Nurse for 9 years before becoming a civil rights activist. Cherry has two daughters, Shauncia Cherry and Tiffany Cherry, and one son, Rico Lewis.
== Activism == [[File:Brenda Cherry at Paris Rally.jpg|thumb|left|Brenda Cherry with Paris resident Patrick Lyons protesting in 2010]]
=== Schoolyard assault === On October 23, 2003, an 11-year-old black student was reportedly attacked by a principal at [[Crockett Middle School]] in Paris, Texas. The child was removed from the school and sent to a detention center. Cherry, along with a small group of people, including the child’s mother and grandfather, staged a protest in front of the school.<ref>{{cite web|title=Curbside Protest: Mother claims son beaten|url=http://theparisnews.com/news/article_aedc00d4-a144-5f26-8dac-3ec73fad0179.html|publisher=TheParisNews.com|accessdate=19 August 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Curbside Protest|url= http://theparisnews.com/article_9034f8b8-af93-51ad-991e-0be9af4bd6a7.html|publisher=TheParisNews.com|accessdate=19 August 2012}}</ref> During the protest, the child was released from the detention center. This event marked the beginning of several future protest demonstrations in the town.
=== Shaquanda Cotton === [[File:Brenda, Shaquanda, Erykah, and Creola.jpg|thumb|Brenda Cherry along with Shaquanda Cotton, Erykah Badu, and Creola Cotton at the Africa Care Academy 10th Annual Educational Awards Banquet in Dallas, Texas]] [[Shaquanda Cotton]] was an African-American student that attended Paris High School in Paris, Texas. On March 16, 2006, Cotton, aged 14, was arrested for allegedly shoving a school hall monitor. Having no prior criminal history, Cotton was tried and sentenced to up to 7 years in the [[Texas Youth Commission]]. During the same time frame, the judge in the case, Chuck Superville, sentenced a Caucasian 14-year-old girl who had a prior criminal history to probation after committing the confirmed crime of arson.<ref>{{cite web|title=Judge keeps juvenile on probation|url=http://theparisnews.com/news/article_51118b41-045a-5e58-98e2-5fa7ffa0ca34.html|publisher=TheParisNews.com|accessdate=19 August 2012}}</ref> Writer Darwin Campbell with ''[[African-American News and Issues]]'' broke the story, which garnered attention to Cotton’s sentencing.<ref>{{cite web|title=Part 1-Willie Lynch and Jim Crow Join Forces in Lamar County to Destroy Black Youth |url=http://www.aframnews.com/html/2006-03-22/lead2.htm |publisher=African American News and Issues |accessdate=19 August 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061105060808/http://www.aframnews.com/html/2006-03-22/lead2.htm |archivedate=5 November 2006 |df= }}</ref> After serving a year and one month in prison, the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' story written by Howard Witt led the case to national exposure.<ref>{{cite news|title=To some in Paris, sinister past is back. |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/chi-0703120170mar12,0,1435953.story |publisher= The Chicago Tribune|accessdate=19 August 2012|first=Howard|last=Witt}}</ref> A large protest led by comedian [[Rickey Smiley]] was held at the Lamar County Courthouse in Paris, Texas.<ref>{{cite web|title=Smiley: "It is time for a new movement." |url= http://theparisnews.com/news/article_0379c3d6-6538-5d24-a001-6427071e6af6.html|publisher= TheParisNews.com|accessdate=19 August 2012}}</ref> Approximately two weeks after the ''Tribune'' article and protest, ShaQuanda was released.<ref>{{cite news|title=Girl in prison for shove gets released early |url= http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/chi-0703310265mar31,0,4450616.story|publisher= The Chicago Tribune|accessdate=19 August 2012|first=Howard|last=Witt}}</ref> Cherry was interviewed by the [[BBC]] regarding Cotton, and the case was included in a BBC documentary by United Kingdom reporter Julian O'Halloran.<ref>{{cite news|title= Fourteen, and at the heart of a race row |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/programmes/file_on_4/7064473.stm|publisher= BBC News|accessdate=19 August 2012|first=Julian|last=O'Halloran|date=30 October 2007}}</ref>
=== Brandon McClelland === [[File:1parisrally.jpg|thumb|Rally for Brandon McClelland in Paris, Texas]]
[[Death of Brandon McClelland|Brandon McClelland]] was a 24-year-old African American male who lived in Paris, Texas. On September 16, 2008, his body was found partially dismembered and mutilated on a farm road approximately 17 miles from his home. The local newspaper, ''The Paris News'', reported the death as a hit-and-run by an unknown truck.<ref>{{cite web|title= Hit-run death still under investigation |url= http://theparisnews.com/news/article_d11c225c-529d-5b19-ba81-3c9d45a5feee.html |publisher= The Paris News|accessdate=19 August 2012}}</ref> Due to the activism of Cherry and the Concerned Citizens for Racial Equality, the case gained national attention.<ref>{{cite news|title=Was his death a hate crime? |url= http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2008-10-05/news/0810040299_1_civil-rights-paris-unknown-driver |publisher= The Chicago Tribune|accessdate=19 August 2012|first=Howard|last=Witt|date=5 October 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title= Two charged with murder after black man dragged to death in troubled Paris, Texas |url= http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/chi-081212-paris-witt,0,3694385.story |publisher= The Chicago Tribune|accessdate=19 August 2012|first=Howard|last=Witt}}</ref>
After dispute about whether McClelland was dragged under the truck or behind it, and while awaiting autopsy reports, ''[[USA Today]]'' interviewed Cherry. "Authorities have not seriously considered the possibility that this was a hate crime. There's a problem in Paris, Texas. I don't see a difference in getting dragged behind a truck and getting dragged under a truck."<ref>{{cite news|title= Another dragging death in Texas raises tensions |url= https://www.usatoday.com/news/topstories/2008-10-24-164308463_x.htm |publisher= USA Today|accessdate=19 August 2012|first=Jeff|last=Carlton|date=25 October 2008}}</ref>
Further investigation revealed that McClelland was last seen alive with two Caucasian men, Shannon Finley and Charles Ryan Crostley, both of whom had extensive criminal history. ''[[Anderson Cooper 360°]]'' reported that the two men were charged with killing McClelland and both subsequently plead "not guilty."<ref>{{cite news|title= The turbulent racial history of Paris, Texas |url= http://ac360.blogs.cnn.com/2009/07/27/the-turbulent-racial-history-of-paris-texas/ |publisher= Anderson Cooper 360|accessdate=19 August 2012|date=27 July 2009}}</ref> Special prosecutor Toby Shook cited lack of evidence to the case, and the murder charges were dropped in June 2009. The two men were released. [[CBS News]] quoted Cherry, "His body was dragged and nobody gets charged? Even if a trucker came forward, that's all it takes? Even the trucker's not charged? If you hit someone, you don't get charged? Nobody gets charged with this? It's not surprising, but it's sad. It appears that a black man's life means nothing here in Paris."<ref>{{cite news|title= Charges dropped in Texas Dragging Death |url= http://www.cbsnews.com/2100-201_162-5065180.html |publisher= CBS News|accessdate=19 August 2012}}</ref> Multiple protests have been led by Cherry, along with Jim Blackwell and the New Black Panther Party.<ref>{{cite web|title= Jasper-style lynching in Paris Texas? |url= http://www.finalcall.com/artman/publish/article_5348.shtml |publisher= Final Call|accessdate=19 August 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title= Protesters clash over Texas Dragging Death |url= http://www.cbsnews.com/2100-201_162-5176952.html |publisher= CBS News|accessdate=19 August 2012}}</ref> The case remains an open murder investigation.
=== Brandarian Thomas === Brandarian Thomas was a 14-year-old African American student at Travis Junior High School in Paris, Texas. In June 2008, Police handcuffed and arrested Thomas at his home for allegedly "touching a female student's butt and crotch" in class. Thomas denied the accusations. Thomas' mother contacted Cherry, who convinced her to take the case to trial rather than accept a plea deal. ''[[Texas Observer]]'' reporter Forrest Wilder documented the case. Cherry views the Cotton and Thomas prosecutions as extreme examples of a larger pattern of racial discrimination in Paris public schools. Cherry stated, "The black kids are punished more often, more harshly. I think they go to extremes; they punish them for little things. A lot of times, they see a black kid as more menacing." Though prosecutors offered a plea deal to Thomas (two years of probation in exchange for a guilty plea), Cherry helped convince Thomas' mother to take the matter to trial in front of the same judge who heard the Cotton case. "It's ridiculous," Cherry stated. "He was 14. You're going to ruin his life because you can't make him plead guilty?"<ref>{{cite web|title= Too black for school? How race skews school discipline in Texas |url= http://www.texasobserver.org/cover-story/too-black-for-school |publisher= Texas Observer |accessdate=19 August 2012}}</ref>
=== Cornelius Gill === Cornelius Gill was an 18-year-old African American high school student in Paris, Texas. On November 11, 2009, Gill was picking up pecans when he was approached by a Paris police officer who questioned him about a stolen car that had been found a few blocks away. Gill refused to be questioned and said a curse word. The officer arrested Gill and placed him in handcuffs behind his back. When another police car pulled up, Gill was lifted and body slammed face down onto the vehicle. Cherry witnessed a portion of the incident and she, along with Gill's mother, filed a complaint with the Paris Police Department. Cherry obtained the video of the incident. Gill was sentenced to 100 days in jail by Judge Chuck Superville. Although the video footage shows no evidence of such, the officer claimed Gill assaulted him while placing him in the patrol car. Gill was charged with Assault of a Public Servant and Resisting Arrest. The complaint resulted in a suspension of the officer, but the suspension was lifted when the officer appealed. The case resulted in an outcry from civilians regarding police brutality and unnecessary force.<ref>{{cite web|title= Video of Black Teen's Arrest leads to more Paris Texas controversy |url= http://www.wiredprnews.com/2010/07/16/video-of-black-teens-arrest-leads-to-more-paris-texas-controversy_2010071612646.html|publisher= WiredPRNews.com| accessdate=19 August 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title= Small Texas Town Seized by Racial Controversy |url= http://www.blackradionetwork.com/small_texas_town_seized_by_racial_controversy |publisher= Minority News| accessdate=19 August 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Video Released of Paris arrest incident |url= http://www.kxii.com/news/headlines/98466019.html |publisher= KXII.com|accessdate=19 August 2012}}</ref>
According to the ''[[Huffington Post]]'', Cherry stated that the ruling sends a message to local police that they can do whatever they want. "What's going to stop the officer from doing that again and again? It makes me fearful," she said. The dash cam video was released after Concerned Citizens for Racial Equality filed an open records request. "We're already in a bad situation here in Paris, and this just makes it worse," Cherry stated.<ref>{{cite news|title= Police Brutality VIDEO: SHOCKING Texas Incident Caught on Tape |url= http://www.huffingtonpost.com/tag/cornelius-gill/1 |publisher= The Huffington Post| accessdate=19 August 2012}}</ref>
=== Bobby Yates === Bobby Yates was a 51-year-old African American man in Paris, Texas. Yates was paralyzed from the waist down due to a gunshot wound during a hunting accident approximately 20 years earlier. His lower body was removed from his hips down due to an infection. On a late night in 2008, Yates made a 911 call to the local police stating that he had been beaten by a 16-year-old white female and two adult males who were at his home that refused to leave. When the police came, the female claimed that Yates had sexually assaulted her. The two males were with her the entire time. The police sided with the female, and Yates was later arrested and charged with sexual assault. Cherry along with her organization held protests and filed complaints on Yates' behalf. After 3 years of legal action, the sexual assault charge was dismissed.<ref>{{cite web|title= Lower Body Amputee Accused of Sexual Assault: Group Claims Racism is Factor |url= http://www.wiredprnews.com/2011/04/24/lower-body-amputee-accused-of-sexual-assault-group-claims-racism-is-factor_2011042418764.html |publisher= WiredPRNews.com |accessdate=19 August 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title= Paris, Texas: ‘Mississippi 50 Years Ago’ |url= http://www.texasobserver.org/forrestforthetrees/paris-texas-mississippi-50-years-agol |publisher= Texas Observer |accessdate= 19 August 2012 }}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> [[File:1brendajimrobert.jpg|thumb|Brenda Cherry along with [[Jim Blackwell]] on the Robert Ashley Show on KHVN]]
=== Aaron Hart === Aaron Hart was an 18-year-old mentally retarded youth with an IQ of 47 when he was arrested and charged with sexual assault. Hart had been playing with a 5-year-old child and they exposed and touched each other's private parts. At trial, Hart's court-appointed attorney called no witnesses on Hart's behalf and failed to obtain an independent doctor for a competency hearing. Judge Eric Clifford sentenced Hart to 100 years in prison on June 10, 2009, claiming that he had no other choice. Within the same time frame, Clifford had sentenced a defendant charged with the same offense, and without a disability, to four years in prison. Hart was allegedly sexually assaulted while awaiting trial in Lamar County Jail.<ref>{{cite web |title= Aaron Hart allegedly sexually assaulted in jail |url= http://crimesandjustice.com/aaron-hart-allegedly-sexually-assaulted-jail |publisher= Crimes and Justice |accessdate= 19 August 2012 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://archive.is/20130121103611/http://crimesandjustice.com/aaron-hart-allegedly-sexually-assaulted-jail |archivedate= 21 January 2013 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Officials look into alleged assault in jail |url= http://theparisnews.com/news/article_19602e8d-c803-520d-aac6-c25522d2b689.html|publisher= The Paris News| accessdate=19 August 2012}}</ref> Cherry and her organization advocated on Hart's behalf. Numerous protest marches were held, led by CCFRE and Jim Blackwell of the Tarrant County Local Organizing Committee. The case gained national attention.<ref>{{cite news|title=Mentally Retarded Texas teen serving 100-year prison term for sex assault of boy |url= http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/chi-paris_for_monapr06,0,5597484.story |publisher= The Chicago Tribune| accessdate=19 August 2012|first=Howard|last=Witt}}</ref> "This is just horrible," stated Cherry in a ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' article after Judge Clifford made his ruling. "How could the judge not take his mental ability into consideration?"<ref>{{cite news|title=Judge won't reconsider 100-year prison term |url= http://articles.latimes.com/2009/apr/08/nation/na-paris8|work= Los Angeles Times| accessdate=19 August 2012|first=Howard|last=Witt|date=8 April 2009}}</ref>
Hart was given a new trial on appeal. Hart ultimately accepted a plea deal and was sentenced to 10 years in prison where he remains.
=== Turner Industries === [[File:Brenda Cherry and Turner men.jpg|thumb|left|Brenda Cherry with Turner Industries employees in Louisiana]] Turner Industries is a privately owned industrial plant with facilities in several cities and states including Paris, Texas. In February 2009, Concerned Citizens for Racial Equality received complaints and photos regarding a noose, racist graffiti, Confederate flags, and salary and advancement discrimination against black workers in the Turner Industries Paris plant. Activism led to a federal investigation by the [[Equal Employment Opportunity Commission]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Racism bedevils Texas town |url= http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/chi-paris_webfeb25,0,4203830.story |work= The Chicago Tribune| accessdate=19 August 2012|first=Howard|last=Witt}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Paris Factory employees file federal racial discrimination, harassment complaint |url= http://www.kxii.com/home/headlines/41178052.html |publisher= KXII.com| accessdate=19 August 2012}}</ref> The findings led to a federal lawsuit which was settled out of court, as well as changes in Turner Industries employment practices. Cherry stated, "One of my biggest concerns regarding the racist graffiti, noose, and other things found at the plant is the mentality of those who put it there. Those same people serve on juries, and some go on to have supervisory positions or other positions of authority." <ref>{{cite web|title=Noose, Racist Graffiti Proves Efforts Must Continue to Expose 'Ghosts' and Truths About Paris Racism |url=http://www.lonestarpowerpages.com/feb-21-2009---special-report.html |publisher= LoneStarPowerPages.com| accessdate=19 August 2012}}</ref> The Turner Industries investigation was one of the largest civil rights investigations ever undertaken in the State of Texas.<ref>{{cite web|title=Nooses, Swastikas, Racist Graffiti Harass Employees of Texas Company – EEOC |url= http://www.bvblackspin.com/2010/04/15/nooses-swastikas-racist-graffitti-harass-black-employees-of-te/ |publisher= Black Spin| accessdate=19 August 2012}}</ref>
=== Roping and bullying of autistic student === On April 20, 2011, a 14-year-old African American autistic student was taken by an 18-year-old Caucasian student into the greenhouse at Paris High School. The 18-year-old threw a rope over a beam and placed the other end around the waist of the 14-year-old. He kicked his feet and beat his hand with a stick until bloody when the 14-year-old attempted to get free. The girlfriend of the 18-year-old student stood laughing and recorded the incident with her cell phone. When the group returned to class, a male teacher took the recording and erased it. After the school refused to discipline the 18-year-old and his girlfriend, or the teacher who erased the evidence, Cherry and CCFRE advocated on behalf of the mother, Tina Washington, and her son. The county attorney refused to charge the 18-year-old student even though it was a felony offense. Several protests were led by Cherry and Jim Blackwell regarding the incident. The case is currently under investigation by the [[U.S. Department of Education]], Office for Civil Rights.<ref>{{cite web|title= Autistic Teen roped by another student, Recording erased by Teacher |url= http://www.wiredprnews.com/2011/07/24/autistic-teen-roped-by-another-student-recording-erased-by-teacher_2011072420998.html |publisher= WiredPRNews.com| accessdate=19 August 2012}}</ref>
== Advocacy == Concerned Citizens for Racial Equality co-sponsored a community reconciliation meeting with the U.S. Department of Justice which was featured in the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]''. "I'm here to talk about racism. I don't see any sense in playing games, pretending it doesn't exist," stated Cherry. "When you go in the schools and see mostly black kids sitting in detention—it's racism. In court, we get high bonds, we get longer sentences. If that's not racism, what is it?"<ref>{{cite news|title= Hard truth, but little reconciliation in Paris, Texas |url= http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/chi-paris-web31,0,922958.story |publisher= The Chicago Tribune|accessdate=19 August 2012|first=Howard|last=Witt}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title= Organizations to hold community forum on school discipline in Paris, Texas |url= http://www.aclutx.org/2010/11/30/organizations-to-hold-community-forum-on-school-discipline-in-paris-texas/ |publisher= American Civil Liberties Union| accessdate=19 August 2012}}</ref>
"This town is being forced to look at things they never wanted to look at before," stated Cherry in an excerpt from ''[[Newsweek]]''. Cherry, along with Lone Star Legal Aid, a local nonprofit law firm, compiled statistics showing that the Paris Independent School District punished black kids eight times more often than white ones, even though blacks make up a minority of the population. The U.S. Department of Education ruled that there wasn't enough evidence to attribute the discrepancy to racism.<ref>{{cite web|title= Problems in Paris, Texas |url= http://www.thedailybeast.com/newsweek/2009/01/30/problems-in-paris-texas.html |publisher= Newsweek Magazine| accessdate=19 August 2012}}</ref> ''[[The New York Times]]'' quoted Cherry, "I think we are probably stuck in 1930 right about now. If you complain about anything, you are going to be punished."<ref>{{cite news|title= Killing Stirs Racial Unease in Texas |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2009/02/15/us/15paris.html?_r=1&pagewanted=2 |publisher= The New York Times| accessdate=19 August 2012|first=James C.|last=McKinley Jr|date=15 February 2009}}</ref>
Cherry has been an advocate for civil and human rights, and continues her work to address race and humanitarian issues.

[[Polish nationalism]] |position = [[Right-wing politics|Right-wing]] to [[Far-right politics|Far-right]] |youth_wing = |headquarters = [[Warsaw]], [[Poland]] |international = |country = Poland }} '''Camp of Great Poland''' ({{lang-pl|Obóz Wielkiej Polski}}, OWP) was a [[far-right]],{{pl icon}} [http://encyklopedia.pwn.pl/haslo.php?id=3949407 Obóz Wielkiej Polski], [[Internetowa encyklopedia PWN|Encyklopedia PWN]] [[nationalist]] political organization of [[National Democracy]] in [[interwar]] [[Poland]]. ==History== Camp of Great Poland was founded on 4 December 1926 in [[Poznań]] by [[Popular National Union]] (''Związek Ludowo-Narodowy'', ZLN) and other organizations of [[right-wing]] [[National Democracy]] political camp, led by [[Roman Dmowski]], to unite Polish right-wing organizations and oppose ''[[sanacja]]'' regime, which gained power following [[Józef Piłsudski]]'s [[May Coup (Poland)|May Coup]] in 1926.Wapiński 1980, 264-265. After merging with National Pupulist Union in 1928 OWP retained its autonomy within newly established [[National Party (Poland)|National Party]] ({{lang-pl|Stronnictwo Narodowe}}).{{Cite book|last=Lerski|first= Jerzy Jan |title=Historical Dictionary of Poland, 966-1945 |publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|year=1996|pages=55–56|isbn=0-313-26007-9}} In 1927 youth branch of the organization was established ({{lang-pl|Ruch Młodych Obozu Wielkiej Polski}}).,{{Cite book| authorlink = Joanna Beata Michlic | last = Michlic | first = Joanna Beata | title = Poland's Threatening Other: The Image of the Jew from 1880 to the Present | publisher = [[University of Nebraska Press]] | year = 2006 | isbn = 0-8032-3240-3 | url = | pages = 112 }} which virtually dominated OWP by 1928. OWP positions in Polish universities among students were especially strong,{{Cite book|last=Crampton|first= R. J. |title=Eastern Europe in the Twentieth Century|publisher=Routledge|year=1994|pages=48|isbn= 0-415-05346-3}} it also gained popularity among workers and the [[lower middle class]].Michlic, p.316 In January 1930 Camp of Great Poland had 35,000 members, in May 1932 its membership reached 120,000. By 1933 OWP claimed to have a quarter of a million followers.{{Cite book|last=Payne|first=Stanley G.|authorlink= Stanley G. Payne |title=A History of Fascism, 1914-1945|publisher=University of Wisconsin Press|year=1995|pages=321|isbn=0-299-14874-2}} Outbreaks of the anti-Jewish violence in Eastern Galicia in 1927 led the organization to be banned in that region that year.{{pl icon}} [http://www.diapozytyw.pl/pl/site/slownik_terminow/antysemityzm Diapozytyw: Slownik terminow: Antysemityzm] After a further wave of nationwide violence in 1933 OWP eventually banned in entire Poland. Government, alarmed by rapid growth of OWP, banned the organization together with its youth movement on 28 March 1933.Wapiński 1980, 299. on the grounds that these organizations threatened stability of the state. After dissolution of the organization, even more radical young members of OWP formed the [[National Radical Camp (1934)|National Radical Camp]] ({{lang-pl|Obóz Narodowo Radykalny, ONR}}).{{Cite book|last= Blinkhorn |first=Martin|title=Fascism and the Right in Europe, 1919-1945|publisher=Pearson Education|year=2000 |pages=53|isbn=0-582-07021-X}} ONR would be banned soon after its establishment, in 1934. ==Organization== Camp of Great Poland was led by the Great Council ({{lang-pl|Wielka Rada}}). The head of the Council, with the title of the Great Camp-maker ({{lang-pl|Wielki Oboźny}}) was [[Roman Dmowski]]; other notable members included [[Tadeusz Bielecki]], [[Marian Borzęcki]], [[Stanisław Haller]] and [[Roman Rybarski]].{{pl icon}} [http://portalwiedzy.onet.pl/29639,,,,oboz_wielkiej_polski,haslo.html Obóz Wielkiej Polski] [[Encyklopedia WIEM]] ==Views== Camp of Great Poland supported strongly religious [[corporative authoritarianism]], borrowing some ideas from [[Italian fascism]].{{Cite book|last=Frucht|first=Richard C. |title=Eastern Europe: An Introduction to the People, Lands, and Culture|publisher=ABC-CLIO|year=2005|pages=26|isbn= 1-57607-800-0}} OWP did not pursue its goals on the political scene, increasingly controlled by [[Piłsudskiite]] [[Sanacja]]; instead it aimed to create a violent, revolutionary movement aimed at toppling the government. Camp of Great Poland even had its own fighting squads organized. OWP [[front organization]], the Green Ribbon League ({{lang-pl|Liga Zielonej Wstążki}}) actively propagated a boycott of the Jewish-owned businesses.{{Cite book|last= Melzer |first=Emanuel|title=No Way Out: The Politics of Polish Jewry, 1935-1939|publisher= Hebrew Union College Press|year=1997|pages=6|isbn=0-87820-418-0}} In early 1930s OWP campaigned for [[numerus nullus]], a policy of complete exclusion of Jewish students and academics from Polish universities.{{Cite book|title=Antisemitism: A Historical Encyclopedia of Prejudice and Persecution|editor=Richard S. Levy |publisher= ABC-CLIO|year=2005|pages=275|isbn=1-85109-439-3}} OWP anti-Jewish activities weren't however limited to political means only. OWP openly incited [[pogrom|anti-Jewish riots]],{{Cite book|last=Haumann|first=Heiko|title=A History of East European Jews|publisher=Central European University Press|year=2002|pages=224|isbn= 963-9241-26-1}} and its youth movement advocated violence against Jewish students. OWP and related youth organizations were engaged in violent attacks against Jews. Those attacks eventually led the Polish government to ban the organization. == Today's Poland == Organization was many times re-established, the first time as political party in Lublin (1993) by prof. Jan Trochimiak. After founded in 2003 as an ordinary association in Wroclaw. Finally, in 2012 the OWP was registered in the National Registrar of Companies and Legal Entities (Krajowy Rejestr Sądowy; KRS) in Warsaw, gaining legal personality. Honorary chairman of the OWP is [[Jan Kobylański]]. __NOTOC__ ==See also== * [[Camp of Great Poland (association)]] ==Footnotes== {{Reflist}} ==References== *{{Cite book|title=Narodowa Demokracja 1893-1939|last=Wapiński|first=Roman|authorlink=Roman Wapiński|coauthors=|year=1980|publisher=Zakład Narodowy Imienia Ossolińskich|location=Wrocław|isbn=83-04-00008-3|pages=}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Polish political parties}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Camp Of Great Poland}} [[Category:1926 establishments in Poland]] [[Category:1933 disestablishments in Poland]] [[Category:Catholic political parties]] [[Category:Corporatism]] [[Category:Defunct political parties in Poland]] [[Category:Far-right political parties in Poland]] [[Category:Nationalist parties in Poland]] [[Category:Political history of Poland]] [[Category:Political parties disestablished in 1933]] [[Category:Political parties established in 1926]]

'''Combat Zones That See''', or '''CTS''', is a project of the [[United States]] [[Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency]] (DARPA)<ref name="darpa-solicitation">[[Wikisource:DARPA Solicitation Number SN03-13: Pre-Solicitation Notice: COMBAT ZONES THAT SEE (CTS)]]</ref> whose goal is to "track everything that moves" in a city by linking up a massive network of surveillance cameras to a centralised computer system.<ref name="vv">{{cite news|url=http://www.villagevoice.com/2003-07-08/news/big-brother-gets-a-brain/1|title=Big Brother Gets a Brain|last=Schachtman|first=Noah|date=July 8, 2003|work=Village Voice|accessdate=2009-10-11}}</ref> [[Artificial intelligence]] software will then identify and track all movement throughout the city.<ref name="tether-statement">{{cite web|url=http://armed-services.senate.gov/statemnt/2005/March/Tether%2003-09-05.pdf|title=Statement by Dr. Tony Tether (DARPA) to the Senate Armed Services committee|last=Tether|first=Tony|date=March 9, 2005|accessdate=2009-10-11|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090901070628/http://armed-services.senate.gov/statemnt/2005/March/Tether%2003-09-05.pdf|archivedate=September 1, 2009|df=}}</ref>
CTS is described by DARPA as intended for use in combat zones, to deter enemy attacks on [[United States]] troops and to identify and track enemy combatants who launch attacks against U.S. soldiers.<ref name="vv" />
Civil liberties activists and [[George Orwell|writers of dystopian fiction]] believe that such programs have great potential for privacy violations, and have openly opposed the project.<ref name="vv" /><ref name="wired-another">{{cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/politics/law/news/2003/07/59471|title=Another Tool For Big Brother?|date=July 2, 2003|work=Wired Magazine|accessdate=2009-10-11}}</ref><ref name="glob-sec">{{cite web|url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/org/news/2003/030801-tech01.htm|title=Spy Project Driving Fear Of Surveillance|last=Sniffen|first=Michael|date=August 1, 2003|work=GlobalSecurity.org|accessdate=2009-10-11}}</ref>

[[File:The Companions of Jehu.jpg|thumb|The Companions of Jehu, from an illustration accompanying Alexandre Dumas' novel of the same name]] [[File:"Les Compagnons de Jéhu" - 4 chap1 img04 jehu.jpg|thumb|Illustration by Gustav Dore to accompany Alexandre Dumas' novel 'Les compagnons de Jehu']] '''The Companions of Jehu''' were formed in the [[Lyon]] region of [[France]] in April 1795 to hunt down [[Jacobins]] implicated in the [[Reign of Terror]].<ref>Jean-Baptiste Monfalcon, ''Histoire de la ville de Lyon'', Guilbert et Dorier, 1847 vol.II, page 1051</ref><ref>David Andress, ''The Terror'', Abacus 2005 p.361</ref> It is possible that they were founded by The Marquis de Besignan,<ref name="canalblog.com">{{cite web|url=http://shenandoahdavis.canalblog.com/archives/2013/02/23/26482023.html|title=NOTICE HISTORIQUE SUR LES VRAIS COMPAGNONS DE JÉHU ♣ PREMIERE PARTIE (1) - La Maraîchine Normande|date=23 February 2013|publisher=|accessdate=9 April 2017}}</ref><ref>{{fr}} Ernest Daudet (1901) [http://www.nemausensis.com/Nimes/Revolution/ConspirateursDuMidi.pdf "Conspirateurs du Midi sous la Révolution Française] ''La Revue du Midi'' pp. 361-375</ref> who also founded royalist underground groups in [[Forez]] and [[Dauphiné]] with the [[Louis Joseph, Prince of Condé|Prince of Condé]] in 1796.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gw.geneanet.org/pierfit?lang=fr&p=pierre%20joseph&n=duclaux%20de%20besignan|title=Pierre Joseph DUCLAUX de BÉSIGNAN - "pierfit" - Geneanet|publisher=|accessdate=9 April 2017}}</ref> Their victims are believed to have numbered at least in the hundreds. They were made famous by the 1857 novel ''The Companions of Jehu'' by [[Alexandre Dumas]] which presented a highly romanticised account of them.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gutenberg.org/ebooks/7079|title=The Companions of Jehu|first=Alexandre|last=Dumas|date=1 December 2004|publisher=|accessdate=9 April 2017|via=Project Gutenberg}}</ref>
==Origins of the name== [[Jehu]] was an Old Testament character,<ref>Emil G. Hirsch, M. Seligsohn (1906) [http://www.jewishencyclopedia.com/articles/8570-jehu "Jehu"] in ''The Jewish Encyclopedia''</ref> immortalised in [[Jean Racine|Racine's]] drama ''[[Athalie]]''. He was famous for having killed [[Jezebel]] by throwing her out of a window. According to the [[Books of Kings]] Jezebel was responsible for inciting her husband King [[Ahab]] to abandon the worship of the true God and follow the cult of [[Baal]] instead. She also brought false testimony against [[Naboth]] and had him killed, and was the cause of much violence and bloodshed.<ref>Emil G. Hirsch, Ira Maurice Price (1906) [http://www.jewishencyclopedia.com/articles/8675-jezebel "Jezebel"] in ''The Jewish Encyclopedia''</ref> By analogy, Jezebel represented the Jacobins of France, responsible for turning France away from the Catholic religion, bringing false testimony against patriotic citizens and executing them, and spreading violence and bloodshed through the Reign of Terror. By the same analogy, Jehu was the force of righteous retribution, come to restore the true religion, and kill Jezebel, her children and all those who had turned away from the Lord.<ref>Charles Nodier, ''Souvenirs et portraits de la Révolution'', Charpentier 1841 vol. VIII, page 79</ref> The reference to Jehu was not universally understood however, and through misunderstanding, uncertain repetition and assimilation with the broader idea of religious restoration, many people referred to ''the Companions of Jesus'' instead of ''the Companions of Jehu'', despite this name being essentially meaningless, as was pointed out by Louis Blanc.<ref>André Castelot, ''Présence de l’histoire'', 1969, p. 205</ref>
The first reference to their existence appears in the records of the [[National Convention]] in a report presented on 25 June 1795 from [[Marie-Joseph Chénier]] on the recent killings in Lyons. His account says:
{{quote|An association of traitors has been organised at Lyon, banded together for the purpose of murder. This company, mixing together religious ideas with massacres, the call for royalism with words of justice and humanity, is known as the 'Companions of Jesus'. It is this company which is spreading a new terror in this commune, more vigorous and more widespread than [[Chalier]] and his bloody accomplices unleashed.<ref>Marie-Joseph Chénier & Antoine-Vincent Arnault, 'Oevres de M Chénier', Guillaume, 1826 p.256</ref>}}
==Activities== On 4 May 1795, 99 Jacobin prisoners were massacred in the town prisons by members of the companions. Over the following days the violence became more widespread and more murders took place as Jacobins were drowned, beaten to death and had their throats cut in their own homes or in the streets. The newspapers encouraged the murder of ''Terrorists'' and ''Drinkers of Blood'', and a list of people to be targeted, ninety pages long, was published in Lausanne and openly circulated. This phase of the [[First White Terror|White Terror]] continued until the army re-established control and various ringleaders were arrested and brought before the criminal court of [[Isère]]. The number of victims of the Companions of Jehu is impossible to know, because there is no reliable way of distinguishing between organised murders and more chaotic lynchings.
An order of 23 May 1796 by [[Louis Antoine Choin de Montgay|General Mointchoisy]] directed that "to prevent the assassinations committed by the Companions of Jesus, it is forbidden to all citizens under any pretext whatsoever to carry swordsticks, throwing sticks, or batons weighted with lead or iron."<ref name="canalblog.com"/>
==Questions over their existence== Some historians, including [[Jacques Godechot]], have argued that the Companions of Jehu never actually existed. According to Lenotre,<ref>G.Lenotre, La compagnie de Jéhu: les vengeurs fantômes, Perrin, 1931</ref> the [[French Directory|Directory]] sought to identify and punish royalists, emigres and refractory priests, and actively looked for people associated with the Companions of Jehu. However although various criminals were arrested, none of them was a priest, emigre or royalist. All those arrested for murder and other serious crimes had been acting independently and there was no organised movement or any coordination between them. The tribunal, under Legris, concluded that there were no registers or membership lists for the Companions of Jehu. Later, under [[Louis XVIII]], many royalists who had played very minor parts in resisting the revolution received pensions or decorations, but nobody ever came forward and claimed to have been a member of the Company of Jehu.
==Les Compagnies du Soleil== While the Companions of Jehu were organised in and around Lyon, a similar group known as 'les Compagnies du Soleil' (The Companions of the Sun) formed and was active in [[Provence]] and [[Gard]]. The company's members considered it a sign of strength to carry the symbol of a splash of blood on their hands.<ref>John Paxton, ''Companion to the French Revolution'', Facts on File Books 1988 p.54</ref> During the White Terror a group of Jacobins was able to take control of the city of [[Toulon]] from 17–23 May 1795,<ref>''Chronicle of the French Revolution'', Longman 1989 p.479</ref> and the Companions of the Sun were particularly associated with the repression and reprisals which took place after the army under General Pactod regained control of the city.

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2015}} {{Redirect|Crusty|things pertaining to or having a crust|Crust (disambiguation){{!}}Crust|the airliner|Tupolev Tu-134}} {{About|the subculture|the musical genre|crust punk}} {{See also|gutter punk|anarcho-punk}} [[File:Posers.jpg|thumb|Crusties]] The term ''''crusties'''<nowiki/>' can refer to two distinct, but not entirely separate, subcultural groups. Particularly in North America, but to some extent worldwide, the term is used to refer to [[crust punk|crust punks]] or [[gutter punks]]. In the UK and Ireland especially, particularly in the 1990s, the term was used to refer to people who are members of a [[subculture]] related to the [[New Age travellers]] movement.
==Appearance== Crusties are distinctive for their unkempt appearance. They are associated with [[anti-capitalism]],<ref>Jones, Liz, [http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1167510/LIZ-JONES-I-hate-crusties-droppy-dyed-skirts-boiled-wool-cardigans.html "I hate these Crusties"], The Daily Mail, 5 April 2009</ref> [[Road protest in the United Kingdom|road protests]], [[squatting]], and [[begging]].<ref name=hetherington >Hetherington, K: ''New Age Travellers'', page 9. Cassell. 2000</ref> Typical dress styles involve [[dreadlocks]],<ref name=cassell>Hetherington, K. ''New Age Travellers'', page 9. Cassell. 2000</ref> piercings, tattoos and dirty clothing, which are generally second-hand or army surplus.<ref name="Cambridge" >Cambridge Dictionary, [http://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/british/crusty_3 "Definition of Crusty, noun"]</ref> Similar to [[anarcho-punk]], most clothing is black in colour. Earth colours are also common. Denim jackets, hooded sweatshirts with sewn-on patches, vests covered in studs, spikes, and band patches are characteristic elements of the crust punk style of dress.<ref name=decibel>Kevin Stewart-Panko, "I Saw Disfear Three Times in Three Days", ''Decibel'', no. 46, August 2008, p. 22.</ref>
Julian "Leggo" Kilsby of [[Deviated Instinct]] describes crust as "a punk-y biker look, more akin to Mad Max. ''[[Mad Max 2]]'' is the crustiest film ever made!"<ref>Glasper 2009, 287</ref>
Crusties have also been described as being typically unemployed youth with no permanent home.<ref name="Cambridge" /> Some are an urban version of the [[New Age Travellers|New Age Traveller]]<ref name=hetherington/> and so may have relatively settled long-term homes.
